Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story: I sat at my small desk, the soft glow of my laptop screen illuminating the quiet room. As a colleague, I knew I should respond to the email that had just arrived—my coworker had sent an update on our project, noting there was no immediate action required, but I still felt the tug of professional courtesy urging me to reply promptly. At the same time, my habit and the rosary at my side reminded me of my deeper calling. As a nun, I had set aside this hour for spiritual study and reflection, a sacred time I tried never to compromise. Yet, just as I opened my prayer book, my phone buzzed again—a parishioner, desperate and lost, asking if I could meet to help her through a crisis of faith. The weight of both worlds pressed on me: the expectation to be a reliable colleague, always present and responsive, and the sacred duty to offer spiritual guidance and compassion. My heart ached as I stared at the screen, torn between the demands of my workplace and the needs of my spiritual community, unsure which path to choose in this moment.
